bibl.title: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Frederick F. Russell, July 24, 1928

div1.p: Carter and Frost, after meeting to discuss a time frame for completing the manuscript, believe it will be ready some time in November. Carter compliments Brown for her dedication to the project.

div1.head: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Frederick F. Russell, July 24, 1928
div1.opener:
Copy Book,
Misel
Russell
Report
The Westmoreland,
2122 California St., N. W.
Washington, D. C.
July 24, 1928.
Dear Doctor Russell:
div1.p:
Your good letter of July 16th. would have been acknowledged earlier,
had I not gone over to Baltimore for the past week-end, in order to talk
over, with Dr. Frost, the work remaining to be done on the History of
Yellow Fever so that we might send you a rough estimate of the time
necessary therefor.

Dr. Frost and I thank that, barring unforeseen circumstances, I
should be able to move back to Baltimore about the early or middle part
of September, at which time he hopes and expects to be able to start
work on the final editing of the revised MSS. This work he thinks can
be finished about the early part of November. It would seem then that
we should should be able to send in the MSS to you sometime in Novem-
ber provided nothing happens to prevent Dr. Frost taking up the final
editing at the time he has planned.

Naturally, sending in the MSS is not the end of our work: There
will still be the galley proof and page proof, which it is essential that
we go over, and the indexing, which cannot be done until one has the page
proof. Dr. Frost does not think that the indexing should take long,
however.

The work on the bibliography is still being pressed to the utmost,
and with very satisfactory results. In this connection, Miss Brown and I
both deeply appreciate what you say about not working too hard in hot
weather, but so far we have managed to turn in considerably more than the
average cold-weather amount of work, despite the heat, which has been
terrific. This, by working early in the morning: late at night and by
the lavish use of electric fans. Of course, it has been hard physically--
very hard at times--but it has also been tremendously satisfactory. etc.
Satisfactory--
Of Miss Brown's efficiency and devotion to the work I cannot say too much.
Without her help the work on the bibliography would have taken at least
twice as long to reach its present status. We're expecting to put on a
“night shift” at my apartment this evening, in which connection--blesséd
be the man who invented electric fans!

I am looking forward with much pleasure to seeing you in September
and do hope that by now you are having a cooler time of it in New York
than we are here in Washington. Last Friday most of the Government buildi
ings closed at 1 P. M. on account of the heat (which the newspapers report
ed as 104). This time also, however, Miss Brown and I “put it across”
by working late at night, but even then Washington was “a good place
not to be!”

With very best remembrances, and onece more with sincere appre-
ciation of your letter of Jyly 16th. I remain,
div1.closer:
Most truly yours, (Signed) Laura A. Carter, Dr. Frederick F. Russell,
Director,
International Health Division,
The Rockefeller Foundation,
61 Broadway, New York, N. Y.
